#Text=China 's consumer prices rise to a three-year high in June as food prices soar 14.4 percent
#Text=Monday , July 11 , 2011
#Text=The price of pork , a Chinese staple , rose 65 % in a year .
#Text=Image : MutHwaBC .
#Text=China 's National Bureau of Statistics released data Saturday showing that the consumer price index ( CPI ) for June climbed 6.4 % from a year ago .
#Text=That compares with a 5.5 % rise in May , which was the largest since a 6.3 % increase in July 2008 .
#Text=The major factor contributing to this figure was the steep rise in food prices which climbed 14.4 % .
#Text=Pork is a major food staple in China , and its price rose 65 % from last year .

#Text=Analysts predicted that China 's inflation would peak in June , but particularly worrisome was the steep rise in the cost of food from the same time last year and up from 11.7 % in May , indicating that Beijing may have difficulty in controlling inflation .
#Text=We must treat stabilising overall price levels as the top priority ... and keep the direction of macro-economic adjustments unchanged . — Wen Jiabao , Premier of China

#Text=China is the world 's second largest economy , having grown robustly in the last two years driven by a 2009 governmental stimulus package of $ 586 billion and low interest rates offered by state-owned banks .

#Text=These were directed at promoting investments in real estate construction and government infrastructure projects , enabling China to lead the global recovery after the collapse of the U.S. mortgage market led to a worldwide recession .
#Text=Now Beijing is attempting to slow its fast pace of growth , fearful of inflation , by restricting bank lending and raising interest rates .
#Text=High inflation along with high property values could hurt the economy .
#Text=Since October , China ’s Central Bank has raised interest rates five times .

#Text=Many factors are contributing to China 's inflation , including higher wages for migrant workers , increases in the prices of food and gasoline , as well as diminished output from crucial agricultural areas cause by drought s and flooding this spring .

#Text=Today , China 's Premier Wen Jiabao indicated that the war on inflation was continuing and controlling inflation was a top priority for the government , increasing expectations that interest rates would be further increased .

#Text=If they signal any comfort with inflation , and inflation is as high as it is now , they could create an environment in which people would panic , and they can have a real problem on their hands . — Tim Condon , ING Asian researcher

#Text=" We must treat stabilising overall price levels as the top priority of our macro-economic controls and keep the direction of macro-economic adjustments unchanged , " Wen said today in comments reported on the central government 's website .
#Text=He had said in March that the ruling Communist Party is worried that a continuing rise in food prices could result in public protests .

#Text=Wen said the government would boost the supply of hogs to keep the price of pork stable , the price of pork being the major contributor to China 's food inflation index and the most closely watched item on it .
#Text="
